In transgenic mice , <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promotes increased lymphoma development by 12 mo of age .
This study reveals that lymphoma develops in B-1a lymphocytes , a population that is associated with transformation in older mice .

The lymphoma cells have deregulated cell cycle markers , and inhibitors of <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , NFkappaB , and <extra_id_0> Stat3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> block the enhanced viability of <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transgenic lymphocytes and lymphoma cells in vitro .

text: Lymphoma cells are independent of <extra_id_0> IL4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> Stat6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling for survival and proliferation , but have constitutively activated <extra_id_0> Stat3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling .
These same targets are also deregulated in wild-type B-1a lymphomas that arise spontaneously through age predisposition .

These results suggest that <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , NFkappaB , and <extra_id_0> Stat3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> pathways may serve as effective targets in the treatment of EBV - associated B cell lymphomas .
Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) is linked to the development of multiple cancers , including post-transplant lymphoma , Hodgkin disease , and nasopharyngeal carcinoma .

<extra_id_0> Latent membrane protein 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is expressed in many EBV - associated cancers and is responsible for most of the altered cellular growth properties that are induced by EBV infection .
